instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got in 3115 board.  green light and charges but no power or fan spin.  found 
no voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
.09v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>  
no power on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> enable
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.31v
<SIGNAL>P3V4_S0_SS</SIGNAL> = 3.34v

Could this be <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> or smc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Great info....
What about PPBUS, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, history of the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
G3h = 12.59v
pbus s5 = 12.59v
pbus s0 = 0v

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v

liquid spill looks like it got a little everywhere, no obvious corrosion or fried parts. found a little corrosion on <SIGNAL>INSN_HS_OTHER_P</SIGNAL> but it has 12.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03. Clock chip corroded? Board cleaned?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 3.3v on both <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> and 03.  y2605 had some rainbow looks on the top of it so i replaced that the clock chip and a few others near by that had crap on them just for good measures,  still same problem.  I have not cleaned the board yet been holding out until looked into everything possible first.  i guess now would be a good time to clean it?
